paragraphs.text: I would be crazy not to ask this question.
Recently, you were on 16 Minutes, and you talked about AI potentially curing all diseases within the next decade.
How would that exactly work? Would regulations slow things down?
Let me clarify what I meant. You can have the scoop on this. What I meant was a platform that could come up with many hundreds of drugs.

Now, whether or not there are all the FDA and other regulatory approvals and things like that, that might change over time too, probably slower than a decade. But that doesn't mean those potential cures wouldn't exist in the world. Maybe it'll take another decade to get them through all the processes and regulation.

On the other hand, I could imagine once those types of drugs are proven out—maybe the first five or six AI-designed drugs—we can back-test whether the predictions were right in terms of side effects and that kind of thing. Then you might update the regulatory protocols to accept the predictions a little bit more, that they're reliable, or statistically know how much reliability there is in that. So I can imagine that changing over time too.

But first things first, we've got to build out our biochemistry and build on top of AlphaFold. We need to build all of our new small molecule design systems and so on, which is going very well at Isomorphic. We've got a good few years of that to do first, and then we'll see about the next steps.

So, accelerating personalized treatment is really what AI will help with. I think so. The thing I point back to is a lot of people are skeptical about that timeline, and it's very reasonable to be skeptical because usually it takes a decade to develop one drug. You're doing well if that's the case.

But it's the same thing we were told when, as a rule of thumb, most people spent their whole PhD to crystallize and find the structure of one protein—five years on average for one protein. And now with AlphaFold, we've done all 200 million proteins known to science in one year, which is a billion years of PhD time. So we've done it once in what was thought to be an uncrackable problem and a grand challenge of biology. This is harder, of course, because it involves the human body, but I'm optimistic it's possible, and we're going to try really, really hard to do it.
